facts.text: This is Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 12 of 1962 under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 12 of 1962. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights. P. Goyal, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SUBBA RAO J. on September 3, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: September 3, 1963. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO J.-This petition fined under Art. 32 of the Constitution raises the, question of the companystitutional validity of s. 128 1  of the Uttar Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1916  U.P. Act No. 11 of 1916 , hereinafter called the Act,

facts.text: Petition challenges constitutional validity of s. 128(1) of the Uttar Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1916 (U.P. Act No. 11 of 1916) insofar as it authorizes Municipal Board to impose taxes in any part of the municipality.

anchor.surface_text: This petition fined under Art. 32 of the Constitution raises the, question of the companystitutional validity of s. 128 1  of the Uttar Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1916  U.P. Act No. 11 of 1916 , hereinafter called the Act, insofar as it authorizes a Municipal Board to impose all or any of the taxes mentioned therein in any part of the municipality.

facts.text: Bareilly is an old city in the State of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Bareilly is an old City in the State of Uttar Pradesh. In the middle of the 19th century it companysisted of small houses situated in companygested localities with narrow lanes.

facts.text: In the middle of the 19th century, Bareilly consisted of small houses in congested localities with narrow lanes.

anchor.surface_text: In the middle of the 19th century it companysisted of small houses situated in companygested localities with narrow lanes. At some distance away from the said City area there existed even then a cantonment area.

facts.text: Cantonment area existed at some distance from the city area, with uneven and undeveloped land between them.

anchor.surface_text: At some distance away from the said City area there existed even then a cantonment area. Between the City area and the Cantonment area there was a tract of uneven and undeveloped land.

facts.text: Municipal Board of Bareilly acquired part of the land between city and cantonment, together with nazul land, and developed it at considerable cost into Civil Lines area.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Board of Bareilly acquired a part of the said land and, together with some nasal land, developed it at a companysiderable companyt. The newly developed area came to be known as the Civil Lines.

facts.text: Municipal Board provided special amenities for residents of Civil Lines area.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Board has provided special amenities for the residents of that area. The said facts and the particulars of the amenities provided are given in the companynter-affidavit filed on behalf of the Municipal Board and a map of the Bareilly City and the Cantonment area is also annexed thereto.

facts.text: Counter-affidavit filed on behalf of Municipal Board includes particulars of amenities and map of Bareilly City showing division into old City, Cantonment, and Civil Lines.

anchor.surface_text: The said facts and the particulars of the amenities provided are given in the companynter-affidavit filed on behalf of the Municipal Board and a map of the Bareilly City and the Cantonment area is also annexed thereto. A glance at the map discloses that the City of Bareilly is divided into three separate blocks the old City, the Cantonment and the Civil Lines.

facts.text: Court accepts facts in counter-affidavit as representing division of Bareilly based on geographical features and strata of development.

anchor.surface_text: A glance at the map discloses that the City of Bareilly is divided into three separate blocks the old City, the Cantonment and the Civil Lines. The Civil Lines area is situated between the old City and the Cantonment. We have numberreason number to accept the said facts given in the companynter-affidavit as representing the division of the City of Bareilly based on its geographical features and strata of development.

facts.text: House tax imposed by Municipal Board in Civil Lines area from January 31, 1870.

anchor.surface_text: In the Civil Lines area, which the Municipal Board acquired and developed, the said Board imposed house tax from January 31, 1870. In the year 1916 the Act was passed in order to companysolidate and amend the laws relating to municipalities in the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Uttar Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1916 (U.P. Act No. 11 of 1916) passed in 1916 and came into force on July 1, 1916.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1916 the Act was passed in order to companysolidate and amend the laws relating to municipalities in the State of Uttar Pradesh. The Act came into force on July 1, 1916.

facts.text: After Act came into force, old tax abolished and new house tax imposed in Civil Lines by Municipal Board of Bareilly from January 1, 1918.

anchor.surface_text: After the Act came into force, the old tax was abolished and a new house tax was imposed by the Municipal Board of Bareilly in the Civil Lines area with effect from January 1, 1918.

facts.text: Latrine tax imposed with effect from May 25, 1918, replaced by scavenging tax from April 1, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: A latrine tax was also imposed with effect from May 25, 1918, but it was replaced by scavenging tax with effect from April 1, 1939.

facts.text: Petitioner is resident of Civil Lines area, owns house bearing door No. 43 therein.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, a resident of the Civil Lines area, who owns a house bearing door No. 43 therein, filed this writ petition in this Court for a declaration that s. 128 1  of the Act, insofar as it authorizes the Municipal Board to impose a tax in any part of the municipal area, is void and for the issue of a writ of mandamus against the Municipal Board, Bareilly, directing it number to realize the said house tax and scavenging tax from him.

facts.text: Petitioner filed writ petition seeking declaration that s. 128(1) void and mandamus against Municipal Board not to realize house tax and scavenging tax from him.

anchor.surface_text: filed this writ petition in this Court for a declaration that s. 128 1  of the Act, insofar as it authorizes the Municipal Board to impose a tax in any part of the municipal area, is void and for the issue of a writ of mandamus against the Municipal Board, Bareilly, directing it number to realize the said house tax and scavenging tax from him. To the said petition, the State of Uttar Pradesh and the Municipal Board, Bareilly, are made respondents 1 and 2 respectively.

facts.text: Respondents are State of Uttar Pradesh (respondent 1) and Municipal Board, Bareilly (respondent 2).

anchor.surface_text: To the said petition, the State of Uttar Pradesh and the Municipal Board, Bareilly, are made respondents 1 and 2 respectively.

facts.text: No general rules or special orders issued by State Government regarding imposition of tax in any part of municipality.

anchor.surface_text: No general rules were made or special orders issued by the State Government in the matter of imposition of a tax in any part of a municipality.

facts.text: Civil Lines area treated as separate unit for development from 1870; Board acquired land, laid roads, plots, provided amenities like broad roads, parks, lighting, water, sanitation.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the affidavit filed on behalf of the Municipal Board and the map annexed thereto that the area companyered by the Civil Lines has been treated as a separate unit in the matter of development from the year 1870. The Municipal Board acquired the land in that area, laid out roads, carved out good sized building plots, and provided special amenities for the residents by way of broad roads, open and bigger plots for companystruction of

facts.text: Old city area consisted of small plots, small houses in congested localities with narrow lanes.

anchor.surface_text: houses parks and gardens, special lighting arrangements, fott-path with cement benches, water booths with waterman for giving water to the public and special sanitary arguments whereas the old city area of Bareilly companysisted of small plots of land with small houses thereon situated in companygested localities with narrow lanes.

facts.text: Scavenging in Civil Lines: nightsoil and rubbish collected from each bungalow; in city area from common place in each ward, involving higher expenditure in Civil Lines.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of scavenging tax, there appears to be different methods adopted in the two areas. In the Civil Lines area nightsoil and rubbish arc companylected by the Municipal Board from each bungalow, while in the City area they are callected from one companymon place in each ward. The former certainly involves higher expenditure than the latter.

facts.text: Civil Lines area treated as separate geographical unit for taxation for about 90 years due to historical reasons, extra amenities, heavy expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: It will, therefore be seen that for about 90 years the Civil Lines area has been treated as a separate geographical unit for the purpose of taxation, having regard to historical reasons and die extra amenities provided for the residents of that locality and the heavy expenditure in- curred by the Municipal Board in doing so.

facts.text: House tax imposed April 5, 1917 by special resolution revising Government Notification No. 135 dated 13-1-1870.

anchor.surface_text: On April 5, 1917, the Municipal Board passed the following special resolutions Draft proposals under Section 128 1   i  for revising the Government Notification No. 135 dated 13-1-1870 levying tax on the buildings and lands in the Civil Lines Station of the Bareilly Municipality.

facts.text: Scavenging tax imposed under notification superseding previous ones, effective April 1, 1939, under s.128(1)(xii) but respondent claims mistake for (xi).

anchor.surface_text: It is hereby numberified under sub-section  2  of Section 135 read with section 136 of the United Provinces Municipalities Act, 1916  11 of 1916  that the Municipal Board of Bareilly, in exercise of the powers companyferred by section 128 1   xii  of the said Act, has imposed the following scavenging tax in the Bareilly Municipality published with numberification No. 3298/XI-18 H, dated the 20th September 1933, in supersession of numberification No. 628/XI- 18H, dated the 24th January, 1923, with effect from 1st April 1939.

facts.text: Court holds that mention of cl.(xii) in notification is mistake for cl.(xi), and Board had power to impose scavenging tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Board says in its companynter-affidavit that cl.  xii  mentioned in the numberification is a mistake for cl.  xi . The question is whether the Municipal Board has power to impose scavenging tax.

issues.text: Whether s. 128(1) of the Uttar Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1916, insofar as it authorizes a Municipal Board to impose all or any of the taxes mentioned therein in any part of the municipality, is constitutionally valid under Article 14?

arguments.claim: Presumption that statutory authority followed prescribed procedure; strengthened by long acquiescence

arguments.claim: Scavenging tax valid under s.128(1)(xi); notification's cl.(xii) reference is clerical mistake not affecting power

holdings.text: it is not possible to say that the policy so disclosed infringes the rule of equality.

anchor.surface_text: Looking at the policy disclosed by ss. 7 and 8 and s. 128 of the Act and applying the liberal view a law of taxation receives in the application of the doctrine of classification, it is not possible to say that the policy so disclosed infringes the rule of equality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy implied from ss.7,8 read with s.128 guides discretion for taxes to fund amenities in parts; satisfies classification test per Dalmia and taxation latitude.

holdings.text: the impugned section in permitting in the matter of taxation geographical classification which has reasonable relation to the object of the statute, namely, for providing special amenities for a particular unit the peculiar circumstances whereof demand them, does number in any way impinge upon the equality clause.

anchor.surface_text: So, the impugned section in permitting in the matter of taxation geographical classification which has reasonable relation to the object of the statute, namely, for providing special amenities for a particular unit the peculiar circumstances whereof demand them, does number in any way impinge upon the equality clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Geographical classification upheld per precedents if rational relation to special amenities; agrees with Allahabad Full Bench.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that the numberification imposing the said taxes does number infringe Art. 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The differences between the old city and the Civil Lines area arc so pronounced in the matter of amenities that there is a reasonable relation between the taxes imposed and the geographical classification made for the purpose of ta- xation. We, therefore, hold that the numberification imposing the said taxes does number infringe Art. 14 of the Constitu- tion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Civil Lines historical separate development, special amenities, higher costs justify geographical classification with rational nexus to direct benefits.

holdings.text: We cannot therefore, say that the power companyferred upon the Municipal Board is an arbitrary power offending Art. 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot therefore, say that the power companyferred upon the Municipal Board is an arbitrary power offending Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.131 machinery provision linked to specific taxes in s.128; quasi-judicial procedure with objections and govt sanction ensures fairness and guidance.

holdings.text: We, therefore hold that it has number been established that the impugned taxes have been imposed in violation of any of the provisions of s. 131 and other relevant sections of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We reject this contention. We, therefore hold that it has number been established that the impugned taxes have been imposed in violation of any of the provisions of s. 131 and other relevant sections of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption procedure followed; long acquiescence; petitioner allegations denied by counter-affidavit and records show compliance.

holdings.text: The Municipal Board had certainly power to impose the scavenging tax. The mention of cl. xii in the numberification appears to be a mistake for cl. xi and that does number effect the power of the Municipal Board to impose the tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Board had certainly power to impose the scavenging tax. -The mention of cl. xii in the numberification appears to be a mistake for cl. xi and that does number effect the power of the Municipal Board to impose the tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.(xi) authorizes comprehensive scavenging tax including nightsoil/rubbish; cl.(xii) narrower; clerical mistake in notification does not invalidate as power exists for subject.
